contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are used to show that there is a specific, chosen time and not just any time. Alternate translation: "for that exact time" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quote: εἰς τὴν ὥραν ... ἡμέραν ... μῆνα, καὶ ἐνιαυτόν
contextId.glQuote: for that hour, that day, that month, and that year

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that God will, indeed, live among men. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The dwelling place of God is with human beings, and he will live with them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize God's eternal nature. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quote: τὸ Ἄλφα καὶ τὸ Ὦ, ἡ ἀρχὴ καὶ τὸ τέλος
contextId.glQuote: the alpha and the omega, the beginning and the end

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the brilliance of Jerusalem by naming a specific jewel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quote: ὅμοιος λίθῳ τιμιωτάτῳ, ὡς λίθῳ ἰάσπιδι κρυσταλλίζοντι
contextId.glQuote: like a very precious jewel, like a stone of crystal-clear jasper

contextId.occurrenceNote: These three phrases share similar meanings and emphasize that Jesus has and will exist for all time. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quote: τὸ Ἄλφα καὶ τὸ Ὦ, ὁ πρῶτος καὶ ὁ ἔσχατος, ἡ ἀρχὴ καὶ τὸ τέλος
contextId.glQuote: the alpha and the omega, the first and the last, the beginning and the end
